Atomically dispersed Fe-Ni dual sites in heteroatom doped carbon tyres for efficient oxygen electrocatalysis in rechargeable Zn-Air battery Zili Wang a b Caiyun Li a b Yukun Liu a Yu Wu a b Sen Zhang b ⁎ Chao Deng a ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, College of chemistry and chemical engineering, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, Heilongjiang, China Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials Ministry of Education College of Physics and Electronic Engineering Harbin Normal University Harbin 150025 Heilongjiang China Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, College of chemistry and chemical engineering, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, Heilongjiang, China b College of Material Science and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China College of Material Science and Chemical Engineering Harbin Engineering University Harbin 150001 Heilongjiang China College of Material Science and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The FeNi-NPC HT composite synthesized from the bio-cooperation process with N/P codopants and Fe-Ni atomic sites is a superior bifunctional catalyst for Zn-air battery. The electronic and functional synergies between the twin metal centers make dual single-atom catalysts (DACs) attractive for oxygen electrocatalysis. The catalytic activities of DACs are largely decided by their surrounding micro-environment and supporting substrates. Modulating the micro-environment as well as engineering the efficient support is challenging tasks. Moreover, both are critical to optimizing the performance of DACs. Herein, a novel bio-cooperative strategy is developed to synthesize FeNi-DAC wherein Fe-Ni dual-atom sites are embedded in the N, P codoped tyre shaped carbon matrix. The configuration matching of Fe-Ni dual centers together with the local electronic engineering of N, P heteroatoms synergistically boost the catalytic activity on the oxygen reaction. Furthermore, the central-hollow highly-porous carbon matrix not only gives rise to a large amount of active sites, but also facilitates fast kinetics. Taking advantage of both the DAC and the substrate, the FeNi-NPC hollow tyre (HT) catalyst scores high in both oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, which exhibits the narrow potential difference and excellent durability. The aqueous Zn-air full battery (ZAB) integrating the FeNi-NPC HT air cathode has a high power density and a good stability over long-term cycling. Moreover, the flexible solid-state ZAB assembled with the polymer electrolyte obtains the high reliability over a wide range of temperatures or under diverse outside deformations. Therefore, this work offers a new green approach to prepare highly efficient DACs with built-in modulated micro-environment and tailor-made substrates. Moreover, it also paves a new way to develop highly-pliable power source for flexible electronics. Keywords FeNi dual sites P, N codoped carbon Bio-assisted stategy Zn-air battery 1 Introduction The Zn-air batteries (ZABs) with superior environmental friendliness, high theoretical energy density and low price are the ideal energy storage devices, which solve the problems of energy storage [1–3]. However, the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on the air cathodes remain the crucial bottleneck for the development of Zn-air batteries [4,5]. Up to now, the platinum-group-metal (PGM) based catalysts, such as Pt, Ru, Ir and their compounds have been proven to be the benchmark oxygen electrocatalysts [6]. However, the high cost, low stability and scarcity greatly restrict their large-scale applications. Therefore, the rational construction and synthesis of nonprecious-metal bifunctional catalysts with high-performance and good durability is highly desired [5,7]. Transition metal (TM) single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been recognized as one of the most promising candidate to replace PGM-based catalysts due to their maximized atom ultilization and unique electronic features [8,9]. However, the single-metal nature of these monometallic SACs greatly hinders the probability to obtain excellent behaviours on both ORR and OER reactions simultaneously. Therefore, the efforts have been applied to promote the multiple functions for the SACs. Among present available strategies, the construction of heteronuclear dual-metal-atom-center (DACs) catalysts is the most promising one [10–19]. Through pairing or long-range coupling of two single-atom sites, the DACs achieve the optimized electronic structures and engineered coordinated environments. Both favor to enhance the catalytic properties on multiple reactions [13–19]. Up to now, a series of DACs catalysts, including the Fe-Co [10–12], Cu-Zn [14], Co-Zn [15], Fe-Ni [16,17], Ni-Co [13,19], etc. have been constructed and show superior performance on multiple electrocatalytic reactions, such as ORR, OER, HER, CO2RR. Recently, Liu et al. [18] summarized the latest understanding of the advantages of DACs for various electrocatalytic reactions. They not only overviewed the recent development of DACs, but also provided the mechanism for their superior performance. On the other hand, the exploration of the highly-efficient substrate with maximally exposed active sites plays an important role on the promotion of the performance of DACs catalysts [14,20]. The carbon based substrates have been extensively studied due to their unique advantages of high conductivity, tunable molecular structure, high adaptations to diverse electrolytes, etc. [21–24]. Through heteroatom doping (such as N, P, S) on the carbon substrate, they will achieve the more chemically active sites for metal coordination and the higher electrochemical activity for local electron structure modulation. Both facilitate to increase the activity and stability for the catalysts simultaneously [25–30]. Recently, Chang et al. [25] report the FeCo alloy nanoparticles embedded in the N, S dual-doped carbon matrix, which achieve the remarkably boosted catalytic performance on both oxygen reduction and evolution (ORR/OER) reactions. In addition, Yang et al. [28] also investigate the Fe-N4 sites on the N, S codoped carbon nanofiber and demonstrate its high catalytic activities for oxygen reactions. Compared with the traditional carbon substrates such as the graphene, carbon nanotube (CNT), and MOF-derived carbon [10–20] with the disadvantage of pricey, the low cost and earth-abundant biomass-derived carbon have attracted intensive interests recently [31–36]. Up to now, a variety of bio-organisms such as keratin [31], butterfly wing [32], spores [33], honeysuckles [34], and polydopamine [35], have been employed to derive the carbon substrate. Recently, Sekhon et al. [36] overviewed the advances of bio-mass derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts and highlighted the importance of their applications in metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Among available bio-organisms, the fungus with inherent heteroatom dopants have been proved to be an excellent electroactive material candidate for energy storage devices, such as lithium-ion batteries [37], sodium-ion batteries [38], potasium-ion batteries [39], alkali metal–chalcogen batteries [40], supercapacitor [41]. In the fungus cells, the fruitful functional groups, such as the amino, phosphoryl, acylamino, chitosan [37–39], favor to coordinate the guest metal ions via complexation and facilitate to form the multi-metal-center atomic sites. Meanwhile, the homogeneously dispersed organics in the cells help to generate the well dispersed atomic active sites throughout the biomass-derived substrate. Moreover, they also endow the local bio-cooperated combustion, which result in the hierarchical configuration and heteroatom doping for the substrate [42,43]. Therefore, it is a promising strategy to design highly effective catalysts with engineered local structure and tailored outside configuration. Following this viewpoint, a new design of FeNi dual-atomic sites embedded N, P-codoped carbon hollow tyre (denoted as FeNi-NPC HT) is synthesized by a bio-cooperated strategy, and it is used as a bifunctional catalyst for oxygen catalytic reactions. As showed in Fig. 1 (c), FeNi-NPC HT sample has central hollow and tyre-like (HT) configuration. The shell of the HT particles has hierarchical structure, which is composed of the small “balls” embedded in the carbon matrix (Fig. 1e). The highly porous nature of both small balls (Fig. 1g) and the surrounding framework contribute to the facile electron/ion/mass pathways and result in the fast kinetics and superior catalytic performance of the catalyst. Experimental results demonstrate the FeNi dual sites and N, P heteroatom dopants in the shell of the HT structured particle. Theoretical calculation (DFT) results propose the engineered dual atomic sites and the modulated microenvironments synergistically improve the oxygen catalytic properties (Fig. 1d and f). Therefore, the FeNi-NPC HT catalyst achieves the good bifunctional properties and high stability during long-term cycling. Moreover, the rechargeable Zn-air battery integrating the FeNi-NPC HT air cathode obtains the high power density and high cycling stability. More impressively, the flexible Zn-air battery with the polymer electrolyte achieves the high reliability over diverse deformation and good adaptability in a wide range of temperature (Fig. 1a and b). 2 Results and discussions 2.1 Characterization of FeNi-NPC HT composite The FeNi-NPC HT composite was prepared by a bio-cooperation process as schematically illustrated in Fig. S1(a–c). In this work, the Aspergillus niger (A. niger) spores were used as biomass template to prepare the bio-precursor. Cultivated from mildewed rice, A. niger spores with rich N and P elements and easy to industrialize show great superiorities for large-scale production. The functional groups in these bio-organisms facilitate the complexation process, which enables the good ion capture capability. As a result, the good coordination abilities of iron and nickel ions in the bio-organism facilitate the formation of Fe-Ni diatomic pairs. Similar phenomenon has also be detected in previous reports [15]. Recently, Sun's group [15] had used the chitosan to coordinate Zn and Co ions with functional groups through a simultaneous complexation process and successfully fabricate the Zn-Co bimetallic pairs. Accordingly, the bio-cooperation is considered as a good strategy to prepare the functional materials especially in the field of energy storage and conversion. In the fabrication process, A. niger spores were used as bio-template to prepare the bio-precursor. They are firstly added to the iron and nickel nitrate solution for impregnation; then the resultant suspension was centrifuged, washed and freezing dried to obtain the bio-precursor. After high-temperature treatment, the intermediate product was prepared. Finally, the intermediate product was etched to remove the residual metal aggregations and resulted in the final product. Detailed preparation process is supplied in the supporting information SI, S-1–1. The morphology of the prepared final product is investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Firstly, the low-resolution SEM image (Fig. 2 a) shows the product has tyre-like configuration with uniform size of 2–3 μm. The SEM image (Fig. S2a) on a broken particle reveals the hollow nature internal the particle, which is in good agreement with the schema of Fig. 1(c) and Fig. S2(b). In addition, the enlarged images (Fig. 2b) on a single particle reveal its rugged and wrinkled surface. More detailed observation (Fig. 2c) discloses the existence of small protuberances with the size of 10–30 nm distribute throughout the shell of the particle. Moreover, transmission electron microscope (TEM) was employed to get more detailed information on the microstructure of the prepared product. As showed in Fig. 2(d), the low-resolution TEM image certifies its tyre-like structure and central hollow nature. Several irregular shaped shadows with the size of 200–300 nm are associated with the fragment of the broken particles that attached on the particle surface, which can be more clearly detected in the SEM observation (Fig. S3). Further enlarged observation (Fig. 2e) reveals many small “balls” uniformly embedded in the shell of the particle. More detailed observation (Fig. 2f) reveals the balls with the size of 10–30 nm. In addition, the high-resolution TEM image (HRTEM, Fig. 2g) and the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SEAD) pattern (Fig. 2h) indicate the absence of the aggregated nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. The results are in good agreement with the XRD results. As showed in Fig. 3 a, the broad peak at 26.4° corresponds well to the (002) plane of the carbon phase (PDF: 75–1621) for the prepared product. Accordingly, both HRTEM and XRD results demonstrate the absences of the metal clusters or nanoparticles in the sample. However, the results are contradictory to the energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) results. As showed in Fig. 2(k–p), the elements of Fe, Ni, N and P uniformly distribute in the carbon matrix of the prepared sample. Based on the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) results (Table S1), it also reveal the iron and nickel element contents of 0.89 wt% and 0.97 wt% in the prepared sample. Accordingly, it can be speculated that the iron and nickel exist at the atomic scale, which are not detectable in HRTEM and XRD results. To clarify this speculation, the aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) was employed on the sample. As showed in Fig. 2(i and j), the highly dispersed small dual bright dots are clearly distinguished from the carbon matrix due to their different Z contrasts. The results certify the formation of dual atomic sites in the carbon framework of the sample. Therefore, the above results demonstrate that the Fe and Ni dual-atomic sites anchored on the N, P heteroatom doped carbon matrix in the final product. In addition, the Raman spectra were employed to characterize the carbon matrix of the prepared sample. As showed in Fig. 3(b), two peaks corresponding to the D and G bands are detected at 1360 and 1580 cm−1 for the FeNi-NPC HT sample respectively. The large D band and the high I D/I G ratio indicate the existence of the large amount of defects in the carbon matrix. For comparison, a hollow carbon sphere (HCS reference sample) is prepared (details in the supporting information, SI, S-1–3-iii). TEM and EDX results (Fig. S4) demonstrate its central hollow nature and only carbon element in the sample. The comparison on Raman spectra (Fig. S5) reveal the lower I D/I G ratio of HCS reference sample (1.05) than the FeNi-NPC HT sample (1.17). Accordingly, the result indicates the N, P heteroatom dopants contribute to the large defects of the carbon matrix for the FeNi-NPC HT sample. Moreover, the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 3c) further evidence the high surface area of 487.3 m2 g−1 for the prepared sample. It is induced by the central hollow and highly porous configuration as well as the defect-rich structure of the sample. The high surface area not only provides more active sites for electrocatalytic reactions, but also facilitates to shorten the ion/mass pathways and promotes the fast kinetics. To gain the in-depth understanding on the electronic environment of the prepared sample, the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) are investigated. The high-resolution C 1s spectra (Fig. 3d) exhibit four dominant peaks at 284.6, 285.2, 286.4 and 288.9 eV, which index to the CC/CC, CP, CN and CO respectively [18,44,45]. The results are in good agreement with the N 1s (Fig. 3e) and P 2p (Fig. 3f) spectra. As showed in Fig. 3e, the N 1s spectrum was deconvoluted into five components, which are assigned to pyridinic N (398.3 eV), M−N x (399.5 eV), pyrrolic N (400.3 eV), graphitic N (402.6 eV) and the oxidized N (403.7 eV) respectively [46–49]. The presence of the pyridinic N favors to anchor the metal atom for stabilizing the catalysts in the carbon matrix [48]; The M−N peak evidences the formation of M−N coordination. Meanwhile, the graphitic N facilitates the rapid and efficient electron transfer throughout the carbon matrix [49]. In addition, the PC bond (133.4 eV) in the P 2p spectra (Fig. 3f) confirm the P dopant in the carbon matrix [18,44]. On the other hand, the weak peak at 134.5 eV indicates the existence of PO band, which is associated with the presence of small amount of oxidized phosphorus species [33]. Accordingly, all of the C 1s, N 1s and P 2p spectra confirm the presence of N and P heteroatom dopants in the carbon matrix for the prepared sample. On the other hand, no apparent peaks are detected in the Ni 2p and Fe 2p spectra. It is associated with their low contents as evidence by ICP results in above discussion. To probe the local coordination and the atomic chemical states of Fe and Ni in the prepared sample, the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) of Fe and Ni were investigated. Firstly, the Ni and Fe K-edge XANES spectra were investigated. As showed in Fig. 4 (a and b), the absorption edges of Ni and Fe in the prepared sample situate between their metal oxides (i.e., NiO and Fe2O3) and the metal foils (i.e., Ni and Fe foils). It indicates the valence state of Ni is between 0 and + 2 and that of Fe is between 0 and +3. In addition, the synchrotron-based extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (EXAFS) were employed to identify the coordination environments of Ni and Fe in the prepared sample. As showed in Fig. 4(c), the fourier transferred (FT) EXAFS spectrum of Ni exhibits two main peaks at 1.57 and 2.45 Å, which suggest the co-existence of Ni-N and Fe-Ni sites respectively. The absence of Ni-Ni bond at 2.20 Å certifies no nickel clusters or nanoparticles residual in the prepared sample. The result is in good agreement with above morphology (Fig. 2) and phase structure (Fig. 3a) results. Similar results are also obtained for Fe FT-EXAFS spectrum. As showed in Fig. 4(d), the two main peaks at 1.53 and 2.47 Å assign well to the Fe–N and Ni–Fe bonds, respectively. Meanwhile, the absence of Fe–Fe bond at 2.19 Å certifies the absence of Fe clusters or nanoparticles in the sample. In line with the FT-EXAFS analysis, the wavelet-transformed (WT) contour plots of Fe K-edge (Fig. S6) show two peak intensities at 4.5 and 7.2 Å−1, which correspond to the Fe–N bond and Fe–Ni bond, respectively. Moreover, the fitting on the EXAFS results were utilized to clarify the coordination structure of Fe/Ni atoms in the FeNi-NPC HT sample. As showed in Fig. 4(f) and Table S2, the coordination numbers of Fe-N and Fe-Ni are 3.1 and 0.9 for Fe K-edge EXAFS spectrum. The results indicate that most Fe atom combine with adjacent Ni atom to form a dimer (Fe-Ni) structure as well as three surrounding N atoms to form the FeN3. Meanwhile, the fitting results of Ni K-edge of the sample (Fig. 4e and Table S3) indicate the coordination numbers of Ni-N and Ni-Fe is 3.1 and 0.8. It also reveals the Ni atom mainly bonds with neighboring Ni atom and three surrounding N atoms. Therefore, the results reveal the formation of Fe–Ni bond in the N3-Fe-Ni-N3 dual atomic sites. Moreover, the above fitting results reveal that the Fe-N and Ni-N bonds are higher than 3.0. The results indicates the co-existence of the majority of N3-Ni-Fe-N3 dual atomic coordination with traces of Fe-N4 or Ni-N4 single atomic coordination in the FeNi-NPC HT sample. On the other hand, the DFT calculations were carried out (Fig. S7). Among the models, the Fe-Ni diatomic pairs achieve the lowest energy, which further demonstrate the Fe and Ni tend to form Fe-Ni diatomic pairs. Based on the above results, it reveal the formation of Fe-Ni dual-metallic coordination on the N, P codoped carbon matrix. Meanwhile, the XPS results of N 1s (Fig. 3e) and P 2p (Fig. 3f) evidence the absence of bond between the N and P atoms. Accordingly, the P atom anchored on the carbon nearby the N3-Fe-Ni-N3 unit, as showed in Fig. 4(g and h). Moreover, we probe the formation mechanism of the tyre-like central hollow structure from bio-mass template. Thermogravimetric analysis of pristine bio-organism (A. niger spore) and the bio-precursor are studied. As showed in Fig. S8, the pristine A. niger spore shows only one broad peak in the DTA profile in the temperature of 200–450 °C. It indicates that only the decomposition reaction takes places for the pristine bio-organism during calcination. As showed in Fig. S9, the resultant original biomass-derived product has tyre-like structure and smooth surface. XRD result (Fig. S10) evidences its pure carbon phase and the Raman spectra (Fig. S11) shows two characteristic D and G bands with the I D/I G value of 1.03. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. S12) show its surface area is 233.7 m2 g−1. On the other hand, two peaks are detected in the DTA profiles of the bio-precursor (Fig. S13). The first sharp peak in the lower temperature (50–200 °C) indicates an acute combustion reaction that takes place locally. It is associated with the metal nitrite and the bio-fuel from the bio-organism, which results in the formation of small balls internal the shell during the low-temperature calcination. The second broad peak on the DTA profile in higher temperature range (200–500 °C) is associated with the decomposition and carbonization of the residual component. After the decomposition reaction, the tyre-like structure with rough surface is constructed. The above results reveal that the well separated temperature ranges of the bio-combustion and the carbonization reactions enable the consequential appearance of the reactions when the temperature is enhanced. It results in the construction of the rough surface of tyre-like structure. Meanwhile, the fruitful functional groups of bio-organism enable the N, P heteroatom dopants on the carbon matrix. Accordingly, the present strategy is an efficient and green route to build tyre-like and N, P codoped carbon matrix with high surface area and abundent active sites, which provides a good substrate for single/dual atomic catalysts. 2.2 Oxygen catalytic properties Considering the modulated dual atomic sites, engineered micro-environments and tailored supporting substrates, the FeNi-NPC HT is expected to be a good candidate for oxygen catalytic reactions. Its catalytic properties were investigated, which were accompanied with the monometallic single atomic catalysts (SACs) of Fe-NPC HT and Ni-NPC HT reference samples (SI, S-1–2) as well as the commercial Ir/C and Pt/C composites. The XRD patterns (Fig. S14) and Raman spectra (Fig. 3b) evidence the pure carbon phase with defect-rich structures are obtained for both samples. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 3c) reveal the high surface areas of Fe-NPC HT (479.5 m2 g−1) and Ni-NPC HT (475.3 m2 g−1) reference samples. Morphological (SEM and TEM) results (Figs. S15a and c, and S16a and c) show their tyre-like structure and the EDS results (Figs. S15b and S16b) certify the uniform distributions of Fe (or Ni), N, P and C elements in the reference samples. Moreover, the HAADF-STEM images (Figs. S15d and S16d) further show the bright single dots inside the carbon matrix, which certify the existence of single atom sites. Accordingly, the above results evidence the formations of the single atomic sites anchored on the N, P codoped carbon matrix for the Fe-NPC HT and Ni-NPC HT reference samples. Firstly, the OER properties of the FeNi-NPC HT sample and the reference samples of Fe-NPC HT and Ni-NPC HT as well as commercial Ir/C were studied. Fig. 5(a) shows the OER polarization curves measured in the 0.1 M KOH at room temperature. The FeNi-NPC HT sample needs an overpotential of 321 mV (η j=10) to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The value is lower than Ni-NPC HT (351 mV) and Fe-NPC (495 mV) and the commercial Ir/C (330 mV). The Tafel plots based on the OER polarization curves were studied to reveal the catalytic kinetics of the prepared sample. As showed in Fig. 5(b), the FeNi-NPC HT sample exhibits a much lower slope (62.9 mV dec−1) than the Ni-NPC HT (67.3 mV dec−1), Fe-NPC HT (91.3 mV dec−1) and the commercial Ir/C (77.5 mV dec−1). In addition, the overpotential (ηj =10) and the Tafel slope of FeNi-NPC HT sample are lower or comparable to the values of the non-precious catalysts with single/dual atomic sites in previous reports (Table S4). Accordingly, the above results demonstrate the fast kinetics and good OER properties of FeNi-NPC HT sample. Moreover, the stability of FeNi-NPC HT sample in the OER process is studied. As showed in Fig. 5(c), it achieves a high current retention of 89.3% after 15 h operating in the chronoamperometric tests. In contrast, the commercial Ir/C reference sample shows the fast current deterioration in the chronoamperometric tests, which only retains 79.6% of the current density after 15 h operation. Therefore, the results demonstrate the good stability of FeNi-NPC HT sample in the OER process. In addition, the ORR properties of FeNi-NPC HT sample are studied. Firstly, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the FeNi-NPC HT and the reference samples of Fe-NPC HT and Ni-NPC HT reference samples are evaluated (Fig. 5f). In comparison with the featureless CV curves recorded in nitrogen-saturated electrolyte, well defined cathodic peaks are obtained for all the catalysts in the oxygen-saturated electrolyte. The result indicates the ORR activities of all the samples. When compared to the Ni-NPC HT sample, the substantially better ORR activities were achieved for the Fe-NPC HT sample, which was almost the same as that of the FeNi-NPC HT sample. Next, the LSV curves of all the samples in the ORR process were investigated. Similar trends are obtained for the LSV results to that of the CV results. As showed in Fig. 5(d), the FeNi-NPC HT sample exhibits the high half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.859 V, which is close to that of the Fe-NPC HT sample (0.871 V) and much better than that of the Ni-NPC HT sample (0.720 V). In addition, the E 1/2 value of FeNi-NPC HT sample even exceeds that of the commercial Pt/C (0.839 V). The Tafel plots based on the ORR polarization curves were further studied. As showed in Fig. 5(e), the FeNi-NPC HT sample achieves the low slope of 56.7 mV dec−1, which is followed by the Fe-NPC HT (63.5 mV dec−1), Ni-NPC HT (70.5 mV dec−1) and the commercial Pt/C (81.2 mV dec−1). Accordingly, the above results demonstrate the good ORR properties of the FeNi-NPC HT sample. Moreover, the rotating ring-risk electrode (RRDE) tests were carried out to probe its electron transfer route. As showed in Fig. S17, the FeNi-NPC HT sample exhibits the high disk current for oxygen reduction and the low ring current for peroxide oxidation. Both correspond to the near-four-electron pathways with the low peroxide production Accordingly, the results demonstrate the ORR process of FeNi-NPC HT sample proceeds via a four electron transfer route. Moreover, the stability of FeNi-NPC HT sample during ORR process is evaluated. As showed in Fig. S18, it retains the high current (91.7%) after long-term (15 h) operating, which is superior to that of the commercial Pt/C (81.3%) reference sample. The result certifies the good ORR stability of the FeNi-NPC HT sample. Moreover, the overall bifunctional oxygen properties of the prepared samples are further evaluated through the potential gap (ΔE) between half-wave potential (E 1/2) of ORR process and Ej =10 potential of OER process (Fig. 5g). A small ΔE value indicates a superior catalytic bifunctional property and electrode reversibility. As compared in Fig. 5(h), the FeNi-NPC HT sample achieves a lower ΔE value (0.692 V) than that of the monometallic (SAC) catalysts, i.e., the Fe-NPC HT, Ni-NPC HT and the commercial Ir/C + Pt/C. Moreover, the ΔE value of FeNi-NPC HT sample is comparable to or superior to the previously reported single atomic catalysts (SACs), dual atomic catalysts (DACs) and non-precious metal based catalysts, as showed in Fig. 5(i) [13,18,50–53]. Therefore, the results demonstrate the superior bifunctional activities of the prepared FeNi-NPC HT in oxygen electrocatalytic reactions. Combined above results, the FeNi-NPC HT sample achieves the high activity, fast kinetics and good stabilities in both OER and ORR processes. The superior electrocatalytic properties originate from its unique features. On the one hand, the highly porous and conductive carbon substrate of tyre-like hierarchical HT configuration gives the abundant active sites and boasts the fast electron/ion/mass pathways. It results in the fast kinetics, highly efficient and durable catalytic reactions. On the other hand, the electron environment modulated by dual-metal-center atomic sites and the N, P codopants favors the intrinsic activity and facilitates the oxygen catalytic reactions. Benefitting from both aspects of advantages, the FeNi-NPC HT sample achieves the highly efficient and superior bifunctional properties for oxygen catalytic reactions. 2.3 Theoretical analysis on FeNi dual sites To further understand the catalytic properties of FeNi-NPC HT sample, the theoretical analysis were employed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The calculations are detailed in the supporting information (SI, S-5). Both the model of FeNi-NPC and the reference models of Fe-NPC and Ni-NPC are employed. The Fe-NPC and Ni-NPC models are the Fe or Ni single atom sites anchored on the N, P codoped carbon. The reference model of Fe-NPC and Ni-NPC and their intermediates are showed in Figs. S19 and S20. Typically, both ORR and OER processes involve four elementary steps. The OER occurs via the generation of OH* from the decomposition of H2O and its further oxidization to O* and OOH*. Whilst, ORR proceeds in the reverse manner to OER, which changes from *OOH to *O and finally to *OH [54–57]. The optimized atomic configurations of FeNi-NPC with adsorbed oxygen intermediates of OH*, O* and OOH* are showed in Fig. 6 (d–g). Fig. 6(a–c) show the calculated free-energy (G) diagrams of all the models in the OER/ORR process at the potentials of 0 and 1.23 V. In the OER process, the maximum value of the free energy change (ΔG) determines the location of rate determining step (RDS). Fig. S21 summarizes the ΔG values of all the models in each step during the OER reaction. For all the samples, the third step with the formation of OOH* achieves the largest ΔG rds value, i.e., the ΔG 3 value, indicating it is the RDS step for these models in the OER process. Among the models, the FeNi-NPC achieves the lowest ΔG rds value, which reveals its best OER properties. When the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V is employed (Fig. 6a–c), the lowest limiting barrier is obtained for the FeNi-NPC among the samples in the RDS step. Accordingly, the above result certifies the superior catalytic performance of FeNi-NPC in the OER reactions. On the other hand, the ORR properties of all the models were also investigated. As showed in Fig. 6(a–c), the downhill free energy pathways manifest that all electron transfer steps of the models are exothermic and can proceed spontaneously at the potential of 0 V. For the ORR process, the minimized free energy change step is the rate-determining step (RDS), which defines the location of rate determining step (RDS). As showed in Fig. 6(a–c), the Fe-NPC achieves the highest ΔG rds value among the samples, which is closely followed by the FeNi-NPC; whilst, Ni-NPC obtains the lowest ΔG rds value. Meanwhile, free energy diagram of all the models at the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V are investigated. As showed in Fig. 6(a–c), the limiting barrier of Fe-NPC model in RDS step is the lowest among the samples, which is followed by the FeNi-NPC models; whilst, the Ni-NPC model obtains the highest limiting barrier among the samples in the ORR process. The above results demonstrate that the Fe-NPC has the highest ORR catalytic properties, which is followed by the FeNi-NPC; whilst, the Ni-NPC achieves the lowest ORR properties among the samples. Therefore, the above theoretical calculations demonstrate that the favorable bifunctional oxygen catalytic properties of FeNi-NPC model, which gives the theoretical proof on the superior oxygen catalytic capabilities of FeNi-NPC HT sample. 2.4 High-performance aqueous and solid-state Zn-air batteries Based on above theoretical and experimental results, it certifies the good OER and ORR properties of FeNi-NPC HT sample, which endows it a bifunctional oxygen catalyst for Zn-air batteries (ZABs). Firstly, a lab-made aqueous full ZAB was assembled by the FeNi-NPC HT cathode, the Zn foil anode and the aqueous electrolyte (6 M KOH and 0.2 M Zn(Ac)2), as represented in Fig. 7(a). The fabrication process is detailed in the supporting information (SI, S-4–1). For simplifying, the assembled battery is denoted as the FeNi-NPC-ZAB. For comparison, the reference ZAB cell based on the Pt/C + Ir/C cathode is also assembled, which is denoted as Pt/C-Ir/C-ZAB. As showed in Fig. 7(b), the FeNi-NPC-ZAB exhibits a stable open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.48 V over long-term operation (3000 s), which approximates that of the Pt/C-Ir/C-ZAB (1.47 V). In addition, the FeNi-NPC-ZAB displays a high areal power density of 226.5 mW cm−2 at a current density of 328.9 mA cm−2, which exceeds the Pt/C-Ir/C-ZAB with the maximum power density of 112 mW cm−2 at 174 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7d). Moreover, after normalization of the mass of the consumed Zn anode, the FeNi-NPC-ZAB exhibits a high specific capacity of 661 mA h g−1 at 20 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7i), which are greater than that of the Pt/C-Ir/C-ZAB (607 mA h g−1). To further evaluate the stability of the cell, the cycling performances are investigated by the galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling tests. As showed in Fig. 7(c), FeNi-NPC-ZAB exhibits good stability during the long-term (150 h) charge/discharge tests. It exhibits voltage gap of 0.63 V and the energy efficiency of 66.3% in the initial cycle (Fig. 7e), and well maintains the voltage gap of 0.70 V and high energy efficiency of 63.8% after 450 cycles (150 h, Fig. 7f). However, the capacity deterioration is obvious for Pt/C-Ir/C-ZAB. As showed in Fig. 7(g), it exhibits charge/discharge voltage gap of 0.66 V and the energy efficiency of 65.4% in the initial cycle, which quickly changes to the large voltage gap of 1.35 V and the low energy efficiency of 31% after 180 cycles (Fig. 7h). Moreover, the long-term cycling performance of FeNi-NPC-ZAB at high current density of 10 mA cm−2 are further investigated. As showed in Fig. S22, the well retained charge/discharge profiles are obtained during 100 h tests, which reveals the good high-rate long-term cycling properties of FeNi-NPC-ZAB. Driven by the increasing demand on flexible and portable electronics, the solid-state Zn-air battery (SSZAB) was fabricated by the FeNi-NPC HT cathode, the zinc foil anode and the polymer solid-state electrolyte, as schematically presented in Fig. 8 (a–c). The detailed fabrication process is supplied in the supporting information SI, S-4–2. The good reliability and high flexibility of the polymer electrolyte (Fig. S23) enable it a good solid-state electrolyte for SSZAB. Fig. 8(d, e, g) show the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles, polarization discharge curves and corresponding power densities of the a piece of SSZAB in different states, from flat (i), low- (ii), medium- (iii), to high-degree bending (iv), as presented in the inserts of Fig. 8(d). The well retained profiles of the SSZAB reveal its good stability and high flexibility. Meanwhile, the SSZAB shows a long lifetime over one hundred cycles at the current density of 4 mA cm−2, demonstrating its good cycling performance. Moreover, the reliabilities of the SSZAB in different temperatures are evaluated. As showed in Fig. 8(h), the stable charge/discharge profiles are obtained from ambient temperature (25 °C) to freezing temperatures (−20 °C) during cycling. When it recovers from low-temperature (−20 °C) to ambient temperature (25 °C), the performance of SSZAB is well recovered. Accordingly, the above results reveal the high performance and good reliability of the fabricated SSZAB in different working conditions, which enable it a good power source candidate for practical applications. Moreover, the two-SSZAB connected in series could light up the light-emitting diode (LED) lights, which further discloses its high potential for rechargeable and flexible electronic devices. 3 Conclusions In this work, we introduce a novel design of the FeNi dual atomic sites on the N, P codoped carbon (NPC) hollow tyre (FeNi-NPC HT) as a highly efficient and bifunctional catalyst for oxygen reactions. On the one hand, the presence of Fe and Ni dual atomic sites and the P dopants on carbon matrix of FeNi-NPC HT synergistically boost the oxygen catalytic reaction; On the other hand, the central hollow, highly porous and hierarchical carbon framework derived from bio-mass of the HT structure provides abundant active sites and facilitates fast kinetics. Taken above advantages, the FeNi-NPC HT sample achieves the high activity and high durability for oxygen catalysis. Moreover, the fabricated ZAB battery based on FeNi-NPC HT cathode manifests the high power density and good stability over long-term cycling. More impressively, the flexible SSZAB with polymer electrolyte shows the high flexibility, good stability and high reliability in different working conditions. Therefore, this work not only designs a highly efficient bifunctional catalysts for oxygen reactions, but also gives a new clue to fabricate flexible power sources for diverse electronics in various working conditions. coredata.dc:description: The electronic and functional synergies between the twin metal centers make dual single-atom catalysts (DACs) attractive for oxygen electrocatalysis. The catalytic activities of DACs are largely decided by their surrounding micro-environment and supporting substrates. Modulating the micro-environment as well as engineering the efficient support is challenging tasks. Moreover, both are critical to optimizing the performance of DACs. Herein, a novel bio-cooperative strategy is developed to synthesize FeNi-DAC wherein Fe-Ni dual-atom sites are embedded in the N, P codoped tyre shaped carbon matrix. The configuration matching of Fe-Ni dual centers together with the local electronic engineering of N, P heteroatoms synergistically boost the catalytic activity on the oxygen reaction. Furthermore, the central-hollow highly-porous carbon matrix not only gives rise to a large amount of active sites, but also facilitates fast kinetics. Taking advantage of both the DAC and the substrate, the FeNi-NPC hollow tyre (HT) catalyst scores high in both oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, which exhibits the narrow potential difference and excellent durability. The aqueous Zn-air full battery (ZAB) integrating the FeNi-NPC HT air cathode has a high power density and a good stability over long-term cycling. Moreover, the flexible solid-state ZAB assembled with the polymer electrolyte obtains the high reliability over a wide range of temperatures or under diverse outside deformations. Therefore, this work offers a new green approach to prepare highly efficient DACs with built-in modulated micro-environment and tailor-made substrates. Moreover, it also paves a new way to develop highly-pliable power source for flexible electronics.
